item.title: Upcoming Talks
item.description:
Topic Speaker Location Time
Talks on Friday October 7, 2016
Primer on Algebra and Number Theory Fengyang Wang MC 4020 17:30
Abstract: This talk will quickly walk through the basics of group theory, focusing especially on transformation groups. If time permits, we will cover some fundamentals of number theory. Please message me in advance if there are any subjects in particular that you would like me to discuss.
Abel–Ruffini Theorem Akshay Tiwary MC 4020 18:30
Abstract: The Abel–Ruffini Theorem is a famous result that not all polynomials with degree five or greater admit roots that can be described with only the elementary functions and radicals. This talk will prove the Abel–Ruffini through elementary means.
Talks on Wednesday October 12, 2016
Ultrafilters Felix Bauckholt TBD 17:30
Information Theory Sidhant Saraogi TBD 18:30
Required reading for information theory: Stirling's approximation [PDF]
Talks on Friday October 14, 2016
The Joy of Factoring Louis Castricato MC 4020 17:30
Types and Object-Oriented Programming Nikita Kapustin MC 4020 18:30
Talks on Friday October 21, 2016
Category Theory Luthfi Mawarid MC 4020 17:30
Quantum Computing Michael Pang MC 4020 18:30
Talks on Friday October 28, 2016
Hacking Rolina Wu MC 4020 17:30
Integration Gregory Patchell MC 4020 18:30
Talks on Friday November 4, 2016
Game Theory Koosha Totonchi MC 4020 17:30
Symmetric Groups Randy Lin MC 4020 18:30
Talks on Friday November 11, 2016
Graphs, Surfaces, and Homology Kai Rüsch MC 4020 17:30
Random Graphs and Complex Networks Frieda Rong MC 4020 18:30
Talks on Friday November 18, 2016
Hypercomplex Numbers Fengyang Wang MC 4020 17:30
Elliptic Curves and Modular Forms Akshay Tiwary MC 4020 18:30
Talks on Friday November 25, 2016
Quandles Brennen Creighton-Young MC 4020 17:30
Naïve Lie Theory Aidan Patterson MC 4020 18:30
Talks on Friday December 2, 2016
Basic Harmonic Analysis Mohamed Ayman MC 4020 17:30
Symmetries and Their Role in Physics Vasudev Shyam MC 4020 18:30

item.title: index
item.description:
Welcome!

This is the site for a not-so-secret seminar on mathematics organized by a couple of second-year math / CS students at the University of Waterloo.

We meet every Friday.

item.title: About
item.description:
An in-person seminar on mathematics.

Could put a blurb about the purpose of these seminars and how the objective is to learn so you choose a topic you don’t have much prior expertise in.
